column8: Policy.Description

The Commonwealth Government<U+2019>s <U+2018>Enterprise Energy Audit Program<U+2019> subsidised energy audits_x000D_
between 1991 and 1997. These audits helped companies identify opportunities for energy savings._x000D_
Under its <U+2018>Environmental Management Program: a Business Approach<U+2019>, the Commonwealth_x000D_
Government provides assistance to companies to take up the challenge of cleaner production and_x000D_
waste management and of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. This program includes an Energy_x000D_
Management Module that helps companies quantify the savings they can make by identifying and_x000D_
exploiting opportunities to increase energy efficiency

Natural gas is Australia<U+2019>s fastest growing energy source and, as a clean and efficient source of energy,_x000D_
has an important role to play in helping to reduce Australia<U+2019>s greenhouse gas emissions. The_x000D_
Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments agreed in February 1994 to implement reform of_x000D_
the gas sector to allow free and fair trade in natural gas. The primary focus of reform has been to establish a regulatory framework to facilitate nationally consistent third-party access to transmission and distribution pipelines through the National Third Party Access Code. This recently finalised Code will enable market participants to deal with pipeliners on fair and reasonable terms, while providing pipeline investors with the opportunity to earn a fair and_x000D_
reasonable return on capital, commensurate with the risks involved. A legislative package to give effect_x000D_
to the Code has been finalised. Through CoAG, all Governments have agreed to implement the Code_x000D_
progressively during the first half of 1998._x000D_
Implementation of the Code will promote competition in the delivery of gas, leading to lower prices_x000D_
and greater choice for consumers and reduced input costs for key exporting industries. In_x000D_
conjunction with electricity reform, the Code is driving integration in the provision of gas and_x000D_
electricity, encouraging optimal energy choice and the increased use of cogeneration .

Electricity retail licensees are required to develop greenhouse gas emission reduction strategy plans, and electricity distributor licensees are required to investigate demand management options prior to expanding, or increasing the capacity of, their distribution systems. The NSW Government has also capped the revenues of the operator of the power transmission system and electricity distributors for the period to 1998/99, encouraging demand management and energy efficiency initiatives. Exemptions include <U+2018>Green Power<U+2019> schemes <U+2014> paying a higher price for electricity produced from renewable sources <U+2014> which now operate in several regions.

Electricity industry reform in Australia was initiated by CoAG as part of broader economic reforms._x000D_
Major restructuring of the industry has been taking place following agreement to establish a fully competitive integrated national electricity market across the generation, retail and distribution sectors_x000D_
by 2001._x000D_
The first stage of a competitive electricity market in southern and eastern Australia was introduced in_x000D_
Victoria, NSW and the ACT in 1997. South Australian generators will join the national market when_x000D_
the market systems are fully operational in 1998, while Queensland and Tasmania will join following_x000D_
grid interconnection._x000D_
The new market arrangements separate the industry<U+2019>s sectors to allow for competition in generation,_x000D_
in purchasing from the central dispatch <U+2018>pool<U+2019> and in the provision of services at the retail level. A_x000D_
system of light-handed national competition regulation of the remaining monopoly (network)_x000D_
elements will encourage increased efficiencies through time, and appropriate investment in networks_x000D_
and in upstream and downstream markets._x000D_
The reforms also encourage the removal of existing capital subsidies and cross-subsidies, so as to_x000D_
promote cost-reflective pricing. This is a key measure for the promotion of efficient competition in_x000D_
supply by embedded cogeneration and renewable energy sources. It will also promote more sensible_x000D_
patterns of energy use through greater incentives for investment in energy efficiency. In recognition_x000D_
of the importance of pricing to efficient, environmentally sound outcomes, a review of the proposed_x000D_
network pricing arrangements will be undertaken in 1998.

The program covers a range of advisory and information services to all sectors of the economy and the community generally. These_x000D_
services cover such matters as basic information on energy use and access to data on high efficiency_x000D_
technologies through networks such as the International Energy Agency<U+2019>s Centre for the Analysis and_x000D_
Dissemination of Demonstrated Energy Technologies (CADDET). NEEP also provides a framework_x000D_
through which the Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments coordinate the development_x000D_
and implementation of initiatives such as product energy labelling, minimum energy performance_x000D_
standards and building energy performance benchmarks.

The Renewable Energy (Electricity) Act 2000, that supports the implementation of the Mandatory Renewable_x000D__x000D_
Energy Target, was passed by the Commonwealth Parliament in December 2000 and the obligation (liability)_x000D__x000D_
and entitlement (eligibility) provisions came into force on 1 April 2001. A separate statutory body, the Office_x000D__x000D_
of the Renewable Energy Regulator, administers the Act._x000D__x000D_
Under the Act, wholesale electricity purchasers are required to purchase increasing amounts of electricity_x000D__x000D_
generated from renewable sources. In order to discharge their liability, liable parties must surrender renewable_x000D__x000D_
energy certificates to the Renewable Energy Regulator. One renewable energy certificate can be created for_x000D__x000D_
each megawatt hour of electricity generated from an eligible renewable energy source in an accredited power_x000D__x000D_
station. These certificates can be traded through a market separate to the market for physical energy. The_x000D__x000D_
renewable energy certificate represents an additional value for renewable energy which when sold, can_x000D__x000D_
increase the competitiveness of renewable-based electricity as compared to cheaper fossil fuel-based electricity._x000D__x000D_
Liable parties not purchasing sufficient renewable energy face financial penalties.

column7: Victorian Government<U+2019>s Renewable Energy Support Fund
column8: Designed to leverage maximum private sector funding for the development of small-scale renewable energy generation projects in that state. Since 2002, the fund has provided $6.7 million in grants towards the capital costs of these projects and has leveraged a further $63 million in private sector investment.

The Australian Government introduced the Photovoltaic Rebate Programme (PVRP) to encourage the long-term use of photovoltaic technology to generate electricity from sunlight and to increase the use of renewable energy in Australia._x000D_
Applicants may only apply for one PVRP rebate for a given property. The minimum size PV system to be installed is 450-watt peak output and there is no maximum size. Please note rebate amounts are capped.

The Renewable Energy Equity Fund (REEF) provided venture capital and managerial advice for small, innovative companies developing renewable energy technologies. The former Australian Centre for Renewable Energy within the Department of Resources, Energy and Tourism had policy responsibility for the program while AusIndustry administered program delivery. The Commonwealth allocated AUD 17.7 million, which was matched by private equity on a 2:1 basis, amounting to a total of AUD 26.6 million over ten years of the program. The identification and management of investments has been undertaken by an independent fund manager. The program is closed.

Generator Efficiency Standards is a Commonwealth best practice program that supports generators using_x000D__x000D_
fossil fuels in achieving better performance in their power plants and, as a result, reducing greenhouse gas_x000D__x000D_
emissions. The program commenced in 2000 and applies to any power generating plant that uses fossil fuels,_x000D__x000D_
whether on-grid, off-grid or self-generating, that meets all of the following criteria:_x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> 30 MW electrical capacity or above; and_x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> 50 GWh per annum electrical output or more; and_x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> a capacity factor of 5% or more in each of the last three years._x000D__x000D_
The efficiency standards are designed to achieve movement towards best practice in the efficiency of electricity_x000D__x000D_
generation using fossil fuels and deliver reductions in the greenhouse gas intensity of energy supply. Under_x000D__x000D_
this initiative, the Commonwealth enters into legally binding agreements with generators to achieve agreed_x000D__x000D_
emission reduction targets._x000D__x000D_
It is estimated that the emissions intensity of electricity production will be reduced, saving about 4 Mt of CO2-e_x000D__x000D_
a year, once all the generators have met the required best practice standard determined for each plant.

A significant investment, of around $65 million of grant funding, has been made in renewable energy_x000D__x000D_
technology commercialisation projects to foster the development of the renewable energy industry in_x000D__x000D_
Australia. Funding, provided under the Renewable Energy Commercialisation Program and Renewable_x000D__x000D_
Energy Showcase, commenced in 1998 and all funds have now been fully committed. The programs support_x000D__x000D_
and promote leading edge and strategically important renewable energy projects with strong commercial_x000D__x000D_
potential, that are technically proven, demonstrate the potential for large-scale widespread application, offer_x000D__x000D_
the prospect of significant abatement of greenhouse gas emissions over the longer term and make a substantial_x000D__x000D_
contribution to building the capacity of Australia<U+2019>s renewable energy industry

The Renewable Remote Power Generation Programme (RRPGP), part of the Measures for a Better Environment package, provides up to 50% of the capital cost for installing new renewable power facilities in off-grid applications. Funds are allocated to relevant states and the Northern Territory on the basis of the relevant Diesel Fuel Excise paid in each jurisdiction by public generators in the years 2000-2001 to 2003-2004. At the programme start, eligibility was conditional upon applicants demonstrating that installations would displace diesel power with renewables. In December 2004, the Australian Government announced changes to the RRPGP, including: increasing eligibility for proposals to reduce any fossil fuel usage, not just diesel; expanding eligibility to include solar thermal, energy efficiency and projects on the fringe of the main grid; increasing the maximum rebate level available for some projects; and extending the deadline for expenditure of funds to 2012. Qualifying capital costs include renewable energy generation equipment, enabling/ancillary equipment (inverters, etc.) and essential expenditures such as installation costs. The programme was extended in July 2007, with the federal government designating an additional AUD 123.5 million to the programme over four years. Around AUD 328 million will be available over the life of the RRPGP. Renewable Energy Water Pumping sub-programme: The RRPGP Renewable Energy Water Pumping sub-programme provides rebates for business, government and other incorporated organisations, to support the installation of renewable energy water pumping systems in those areas of Australia not close to a main-grid. The sub-programme aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by decreasing reliance on diesel fuel for remote water pumping applications. This sub-programme provides rebates for the renewable energy components of water pumps that displace diesel engine powered pumps in off-grid applications. Residential and Medium-scale (RM) sub-programme: The RRPGP Residential and Medium-scale (RM) sub-programme commenced on 23 July 2007. This sub-programme provides rebates for households, communities, not-for-profit, business, government and other organisations, in those areas of Australia that are not close to a main grid, to support the installation of renewable generation systems (where existing RRPGP sub-programmes are not available). Rebates of up to 50% of the capital cost of renewable generation and essential enabling equipment are available to applicants that fully comply with the eligibility requirements and procedures outlined in the RM sub-programme guidelines. The Residential and Medium-scale (RM) and Renewable Energy Water Pumping sub-programmes are not currently available in Western Australia, Northern Territory or Tasmania where existing RRPGP sub programmes are still available. In February 2008, AUD 42 million was not rephased into future years and was identified as budget savings. Funding for RRPGP closed on 22 June 2009 to new applicants in all states except Western Australia, as funding for the programme has now been committed.

Many of the initiatives in the Action Agenda are supported by the Industry_x000D__x000D_
Development component of the Renewable Energy Commercialisation Program, from which $6 million has_x000D__x000D_
been allocated for grants to assist the industry in overcoming barriers to growth. Projects include_x000D__x000D_
development of a national training package in renewable energy, quality accreditation for installers of_x000D__x000D_
renewable systems, laboratory-testing facilities for quality control of renewable equipment, national resource_x000D__x000D_
mapping for bioenergy, and best practice guidelines for development of wind farms.

The Local Greenhouse Action measure is Cross-sectoral in nature, targeting the Stationary Energy and Transport subsectors, and the Waste sector._x000D_
The Australian Government<U+2019>s Local Greenhouse Action measure was announced in the 2004<U+2013>05 Federal Budget. It integrates the following previously separate programmes: Cities for Climate Protection<U+2122> Australia (CCP<U+2122> Australia); Travel Demand Management; Household Greenhouse Action; and Cool Communities. These programmes have been streamlined in order to engage a larger number of Australian households and communities in greenhouse action over the long term, and on a more cost-effective basis. Funding of $13.6 million over four years to 2007<U+2013>08 has been committed to this measure to encourage and facilitate greenhouse gas abatement by local governments and the community through: maintaining and increasing abatement from the operations of local government through CCP<U+2122> Australia, using local government as the key conduit to the community by providing incentives for local government to take action with local households, transport systems and businesses, leveraging the complementary role of local government in planning and infrastructure provision, increasing the information and resources available to encourage community greenhouse gas abatement. Abatement and capacity building will be achieved through targeted grant programmes, partnership projects with various levels of government, the provision of information, the commissioning of research, and the provision of programme support through the International Council for Local Environmental Initiatives. The Travel Demand Management Programme complements TravelSmart activities already underway, as reported in Australia<U+2019>s Third National Communication. Under the initiative, the Australian Government is engaging with state, territory and local governments and communities to support various approaches to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from passenger transport, particularly in urban centres. CCP<U+2122> Australia now has 205 participating local governments representing nearly 80% of the Australian population, making it the world<U+2019>s largest and most effective CCP<U+2122>_x000D__x000D_
campaign.

The Greenhouse Challenge Plus Programme is a Crosssectoral measure that targets the Stationary Energy, Transport and Fugitive Emissions from Fuels subsectors and the Industrial Processes, Waste and Land Use, Land Use Change and Forestry sectors. _x000D_
The Australian Government<U+2019>s $31.6 million Greenhouse Challenge Plus Programme was announced in 2004. It builds upon the success of the Greenhouse Challenge Programme (reported in Australia<U+2019>s Third National Communication), to strengthen the partnership between the Australian Government and industry to abate greenhouse gas emissions._x000D__x000D_
The programme is designed to help companies reduce their emissions, integrate greenhouse issues into business decision making and accelerate the uptake of energy efficiency. The new Greenhouse Challenge Plus Programme recognises businesses<U+2019> different levels of response to managing greenhouse gas emissions through a tiered approach to programme membership, incorporating partnerships on a_x000D__x000D_
voluntary, incentive-based and compulsory basis. All existing members of the Greenhouse Challenge programmes became members of Greenhouse Challenge Plus. Greenhouse Challenge Plus has around 800 participants, representing almost 50% of greenhouse gas emissions from industry. In particular, it has excellent coverage of companies in key sectors, including electricity supply, oil and gas, aluminium, cement, mining and manufacturing. Most member companies participate voluntarily, but from July 2006, companies that receive more than $3 million per year of business fuel credits will be required to join the programme. In addition, a new requirement for proponents of major energy resource developments to join Greenhouse Challenge Plus is being developed._x000D__x000D_
Under Greenhouse Challenge Plus, businesses measure and monitor greenhouse gas emissions and deliver maximum practical greenhouse gas abatement by working towards specific milestones set out under individual agreements._x000D__x000D_
The Australian Government provides administrative and technical support for the programme._x000D__x000D_
The programme also allows companies that wish to go further in reducing their greenhouse gas emissions to be_x000D__x000D_
identified as Greenhouse Leaders by agreeing to achieve a greenhouse gas abatement goal and report publicly on the_x000D__x000D_
outcomes._x000D__x000D_
Greenhouse Challenge Plus also integrates the Generator Efficiency Standards (GES) and the Greenhouse Friendly programmes (as reported in Australia<U+2019>s Third National Communication) into a single streamlined programme. This integration is being achieved through common verification_x000D__x000D_
and reporting arrangements and through a new online reporting tool._x000D__x000D_
By May 2004, 17 companies, representing 85% of Australian electricity generation capacity, had signed up to the GES, and some have already started implementing their action plans. The Greenhouse Challenge, GES, and Greenhouse Friendly_x000D__x000D_
components of Greenhouse Challenge Plus together are expected to lead to abatement of an estimated 15.8 Mt CO2 -e_x000D__x000D_
in 2010.

The Greenhouse Gas Abatement Programme is a Crosssectoral measure that targets the Stationary Energy, Transport and Fugitive Emissions from Fuels subsectors and the Industrial Processes and Land Use, Land Use Change and Forestry sectors. The Greenhouse Gas Abatement Programme (GGAP)_x000D_
was established as part of the 1999 Measures for a Better Environment package. As reported in Australia<U+2019>s Third National Communication, the programme leverages private sector investment in activities or technologies that are likely to result in substantial reductions in greenhouse gas emissions or sink enhancement particularly in the period 2008<U+2013>12._x000D_
GGAP projects approved to date include co-generation,_x000D_
energy efficiency, travel demand management, alternative fuels, coal mine gas technologies and fuel conversion. As of mid-2004, 12 projects approved by ministers are on track to deliver abatement in the Kyoto target period. In the 2004<U+2013>05 Federal Budget, the Australian Government announced that the third funding round of GGAP would be the last, and re-allocated uncommitted GGAP funds to Climate Change Strategy initiatives that include a strong focus on strategic, long-term abatement and innovative technologies. GGAP is expected to generate cost-effective emissions reductions during the Kyoto Protocol target period 2008<U+2013>12. The estimated average abatement cost (from government funding) is $5.5 per tonne of CO2_x000D_
 for the first two funding rounds of GGAP based on 2003 projections. It is projected that GGAP will abate an estimated 6.1 Mt CO2 -e in 2010.

The Low Emissions Technology Demonstration Fund is a Cross-sectoral measure that targets the Stationary Energy, Transport and Fugitive Emissions from Fuels subsectors._x000D_
The Australian Government has established a $500 million Low Emissions Technology Demonstration Fund to support industry-led projects to demonstrate the commercial viability_x000D_
of new technologies or processes or the application of overseas_x000D_
technologies or processes to Australian circumstances to deliver_x000D_
long-term, large-scale greenhouse gas emission reductions._x000D_
The fund is technology neutral and will encompass renewable_x000D_
and fossil fuel supply technologies as well as energy efficiency,_x000D_
and can be for either stationary or transport energy projects._x000D_
To be eligible for support under the fund, technologies will have_x000D_
to be commercially available by 2020<U+2013>30 and able to reduce_x000D_
greenhouse gas emissions from the energy sector by at least 2%_x000D_
per annum from 2030._x000D_
The fund was announced through the release of the Australian_x000D_
Government<U+2019>s 2004 Energy White Paper Securing Australia<U+2019>s_x000D_
Energy Future, and has been designed to leverage at least_x000D_
$1 billion dollars in private-sector investment. The fund will_x000D_
play a major role in reducing Australia<U+2019>s greenhouse signature_x000D_
over the longer term while maintaining the viability of its_x000D_
energy and energy-dependent industries. In light of the longer_x000D_
term focus of this programme, projects will deliver emissions_x000D_
abatement beyond 2010._x000D_

Launched initially in 1997 in NSW by SEDA, the Green Power program was one of the first of its type in the_x000D__x000D_
world. Today, the National Green Power Accreditation Program, established in May 2000, is offered nationally through joint collaboration by participating State and Territory government agencies in NSW, Victoria,_x000D__x000D_
Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and the ACT.Green Power aims to facilitate the installation of new renewable energy generators across Australia, beyond mandatory renewable requirements. Under the programme, customers can elect to pay a premium to their energy retailers for the supply of electricity generated from renewable sources (solar, wind, biomass, hydro and geothermal). Accredited energy suppliers then agree to buy an amount of energy from renewable sources equivalent to the amount nominated by participating consumers and businesses. The programme has similar objectives to MRET<U+2014>to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from the electricity generation sector and drive investment in renewable energy projects<U+2014> but whereas MRET is a mandatory  (legislated) requirement, Green Power relies on consumers voluntarily paying a premium. Green Power provided by retailers to meet customer demand cannot be <U+2018>double counted<U+2019> to contribute to meeting their MRET obligations. Ongoing compliance of products is checked regularly_x000D_
via financial and technical status reports provided by the energy supplier. Independent audits are carried out by the New South Wales Department of Energy Utilities_x000D_
and Sustainability, as programme manager. Participating state and territory governments promote and help energy suppliers to promote Green Power accredited programmes_x000D_
to increase participation and therefore demand. Several of the state governments also provide financial assistance for the development of new generators, and have policies for_x000D_
government bodies to purchase Green Power.

In response to an emerging challenge to the effective management of increasing amounts of wind power on electricity networks, the Australian Government has committed $14 million over five years from 2004<U+2013>05 to the_x000D_
development and installation of systems to provide accurate_x000D_
forecasts of wind output. This capability will facilitate greater penetration of wind into energy markets, increasing the value of wind energy to electricity retailers, and allow_x000D_
for more strategic planning of new wind farms._x000D_
The forecasting capability is expected to be implemented in 2006, and will be expanded over the following three years to improve performance and maximise accuracy. Emissions_x000D_
reductions have not been estimated separately from MRET.

The Australian Government is providing funding of $20.4 million over four years to identify, support the development and demonstration of, and promote advanced storage technologies that have strong potential to significantly increase the penetration of electricity generated by intermittent renewable energy sources into Australia<U+2019>s energy supply. Announced as part of measures contained in Securing Australia<U+2019>s Energy Future, the initiative is designed to take advantage of Australia<U+2019>s technological leadership in a number of storage technologies that have the potential to reduce greenhouse gas emissions over the medium to long term. It is expected that proposals under this initiative will be assessed in 2006. Emissions  eductions have not been estimated as this measure is focused on longer-term abatement_x000D__x000D_
beyond 2012.

Under the Renewable Energy Development Initiative (REDI), the Australian Government will provide $100 million over seven years from 2004<U+2013>05 to support the development of renewable energy technology products, processes and services that have strong early-stage commercialisation and greenhouse gas abatement potential. The programme aims to support the international competitiveness of Australian industry by encouraging innovation through increasing the level of research and development, proof-of-concept and early-stage commercialisation activities undertaken by Australian companies. The assessment of project proposals commenced in August 2005. Emissions reductions have not been estimated as this measure is focused on longer-term abatement beyond 2012.

The Prime Minister announced in 1997 the introduction of a Mandatory Renewable Energy Target (MRET) for the uptake of additional renewable energy in power supplies._x000D_
The MRET scheme sought to increase the contribution of renewable energy sources to Australia<U+2019>s electricity mix by 9,500 GWh per year by 2010, at which time, renewable energy generation is expected to have increased by more than 50% above 1997 levels. Under the applicable legislation, wholesale electricity purchasers are required to purchase increasing amounts of electricity generated from renewable sources. Following a review of the Renewable Energy (Electricity) Act_x000D_
2000 in 2003, the Australian Government agreed to improve the operational and administrative efficiency of the measure and increase opportunities for solar and biomass energy. The scheme is projected to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by an estimated 6.6 Mt CO2 -e in 2010.

In August 2004, the Ministerial Council on Energy announced a comprehensive package of measures comprising Stage One of the National Framework for Energy Efficiency (NFEE). The NFEE package integrates existing energy efficiency measures (as reported in Australia<U+2019>s Third National Communication) with a range of new measures under the Climate Change Strategy. Together, the Australian Government and state and territory governments have committed $33 million to the NFEE package.

column7: State and territory low emissions technology measures
column8:
In 2003, the Queensland Government committed $9 million over five years to the Centre for Low Emission Technology, in conjunction with the Commonwealth Science and Industrial Research Organisation, Australian Coal Research, industry partners and the University of Queensland. The Centre facilitates research, development and demonstration of the key technologies that have the potential to significantly improve the environmental performance of coal-fired power stations, by reducing greenhouse gas emissions to near zero levels. The Centre will also conduct research into the policy issues surrounding low emission coal technologies._x000D_
The Victorian Government<U+2019>s $106 million Energy Technology and Innovation Strategy (ETIS) was launched in May 2005. Developed to facilitate a coordinated approach to the advancement of low emissions energy technologies to commercial-ready stage, the ETIS supports the progression of new technologies through their innovation processes, particularly where a market gap has been identified. _x000D_
Current projects include: the large-scale demonstration of clean brown coal technology power plants, investment in research, development and early stage demonstration projects as a base for later commercialisation, a trial of geo-sequestration, investment to support construction of a pre-commercial plant demonstrating a coal drying technology known as mechanical thermal expression.

The Queensland Government<U+2019>s 13% Gas Scheme came into effect on 1 January 2005. It is a major regulatory measure of the Queensland Government<U+2019>s Cleaner Energy Strategy and is designed to foster greater use of gas in that state by requiring electricity retailers and some other liable parties, such as self-generators and power stations selling electricity to end-users, to source at least 13% of the electricity they sell_x000D_
or use in Queensland from gas fired generation._x000D_
On 1 January 2003 the New South Wales Government established a mandatory Greenhouse Gas Abatement Scheme (GGAS), which requires liable parties (electricity retailers and large electricity users choosing to participate) to meet mandatory annual targets for greenhouse emissions, or pay a financial penalty. Annual targets for the scheme are based on per capita greenhouse emissions in New South Wales. Electricity retailers can meet their benchmark through purchasing increased amounts of electricity from less greenhouse-intensive sources, reduced consumer demand and the purchase of carbon sinks to offset emissions._x000D_
The Australian Capital Territory introduced its GGAS on 1 January 2005, compelling electricity retailers to source, over time, an increasing percentage of their product from cleaner or renewable energy sources.

column7: Low Emissions Technology and Abatement Programme_x000D_ (LETA)
column8:
The Low Emissions Technology and Abatement (LETA) Programme was announced by the Australian Government in the 2004<U+2013>05 Federal Budget as a $26.9 million measure designed to encourage technologies that reduce energy demand and emission intensity, in business, industry and local communities. The Australian Government agreed on the following four LETA themes through which funds will be allocated and the programme evaluated: strategic abatement, renewables, fossil fuels,_x000D__x000D_
geosequestration<U+2014>monitoring pilot project._x000D__x000D_
LETA is designed to complement other climate change programmes as a comprehensive approach to meeting the emissions management objectives of the Australian Government<U+2019>s Climate Change Strategy. Assessment, approval and implementation of proposals is expected to begin in the latter part of 2005.

The Australian Government will continue to work collaboratively with the state and territory governments to develop an open, efficient and competitive energy market that is attractive to investors, encourages a greater focus on energy efficiency, and will lead to a decrease in the greenhouse intensity of Australia<U+2019>s energy supply. The reform agenda includes increasing the interconnection of regional electricity markets, and measures to increase demandside participation across a number of markets._x000D_
In December 2003, COAG announced its commitment to a renewed programme of reform for the period to 2006 involving, as a first step, the establishment of a single energy regulator, the Australian Energy Regulator, and a single rule-making and market development body, the Australian Energy Market Commission, replacing 17 existing bodies and_x000D_
providing certainty and stability to energy markets. Current reform policies focus on the areas of transmission planning, energy user participation and removal of impediments to natural gas use._x000D_
Ongoing EMR will be complemented by a detailed suite of measures designed to increase the uptake of commercial opportunities to improve energy efficiency. The Australian Government will also work with states and territories to identify and overcome energy market rules that provide impediments to the uptake of smaller-scale local generation (distributed generation), including renewable energy sources. _x000D_
State governments have also taken specific measures in_x000D_
relation to EMR. In July 2003, full retail contestability was_x000D_
introduced into the energy markets of New South Wales,_x000D_
Victoria, South Australia and the Australian Capital Territory._x000D_
Households and small businesses in these jurisdictions are_x000D_
now able to choose the supplier from whom they buy their_x000D_
energy. The aim is to allow all electricity and gas customers_x000D_
to have greater choice in their energy supply, and to compare_x000D_
prices and services.

The Large-scale RET of 33,000 GWh by 2020 encourages investment in large-scale renewable energy projects. Eligible large-scale renewable energy generators, like solar and wind farms, hydro-electric and biomass power_x000D__x000D_
stations, can create certificates under the Large-scale Renewable Energy Target. Electricity retailers are legally_x000D__x000D_
obligated to buy and surrender a certain amount of certificates to the Clean Energy Regulator each year. This_x000D__x000D_
operates as a subsidy to renewable energy generators._x000D__x000D_
In August 2017, more than 70 per cent of the estimated capacity required to reach the target had been accredited.

The SRES helps home-owners and small businesses to install eligible small-scale renewable energy systems and solar hot water systems. The Small-scale Renewable Energy Scheme assists homeowners and small businesses with upfront costs of_x000D__x000D_
installing small-scale (less than 100 kilowatt capacity) wind, hydro and solar panel systems. This scheme has_x000D__x000D_
assisted Australian households to install more than 1.8 million solar PV systems and one million solar water_x000D__x000D_
heater systems._x000D__x000D_
In August 2017, Australia hit a milestone of 6000 megawatt capacity across 2.8 million small-scale installations_x000D__x000D_
of renewable energy systems such as solar PV systems, solar water heaters and air source heat pumps. That is_x000D__x000D_
enough to power 1.8 million homes.

The Greenhouse Gas Abatement Program (GGAP) was a competitive grants program designed to reduce Australia<U+2019>s net greenhouse gas emissions by supporting activities that 1) are likely to result in substantial emissions reductions, or 2) offset greenhouse emissions.

Requires liable parties (electricity retailers and large electricity users who choose to participate) to meet mandatory annual targets for reducing or offsetting greenhouse gas emissions from the production of electricity that they supply or use.

The Australian Government<U+2019>s $75 million Solar Cities_x000D__x000D_
initiative aims to encourage businesses and communities to_x000D__x000D_
explore new sustainable models of electricity supply and use_x000D__x000D_
in order to better manage peak electricity demand._x000D__x000D_
Announced by the Prime Minister in 2004 as part of the_x000D__x000D_
Energy White Paper Securing Australia<U+2019>s Energy Future,_x000D__x000D_
Solar Cities will develop innovative approaches to electricity_x000D__x000D_
pricing that deliver more effective signals to energy users._x000D__x000D_
These will be integrated with the concentrated uptake of_x000D__x000D_

The CPRS will commence on 1 July 2011, and will be_x000D__x000D_

The CPRS legislation was defeated in the Australian_x000D__x000D_

The Climate Change Authority is currently conducting a review into Australia<U+2019>s pollution_x000D__x000D_

column7: Financial Support in Energy Projects Clean Energy Finance Corporation (CEFC)
column8:
The Clean Energy Finance Corporation (CEFC), announced as part of the Clean Energy_x000D__x000D_

The CEFC will seek to co-finance clean energy projects with the private sector, working_x000D__x000D_

two streams, each with half of the allocated funding._x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> The renewable energy stream will invest in renewable technologies, which may_x000D__x000D_
include geothermal, wave energy and large scale solar power generation._x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> The clean energy stream will invest more broadly; for example, in low-emissions cogeneration technology, but will still be able to invest in renewable energy._x000D__x000D_
The CEFC will operate with the expectation of minimal budgetary assistance and make_x000D__x000D_
its investment decisions, independently of the Government, based on rigorous_x000D__x000D_

A variety of funding tools will be used to support projects, including loans on commercial_x000D__x000D_
or concessional terms and equity investments. To ensure that the CEFC has continuing_x000D__x000D_

The National Energy Efficiency Initiative: Smart Grid, Smart City is a $100 million_x000D__x000D_

designed to:_x000D__x000D_

Up to 30 000 households will participate in the project which runs between 2010 and_x000D__x000D_

smart grid technologies becoming available to Government, industry, research and_x000D__x000D_
educational institutions and residential consumers. Key achievements to date include

The Energy Efficiency Opportunities program is targeted at addressing information_x000D__x000D_
barriers to the uptake of energy efficiency. Under the program the Government requires_x000D__x000D_
Australia<U+2019>s largest energy using corporations that use more than 0.5 petajoules (PJ) of_x000D__x000D_
energy per year (equivalent to 10,000 households) to undertake comprehensive_x000D__x000D_
assessments of their energy use. Over 300 corporations, representing 65 per cent of_x000D__x000D_
Australia<U+2019>s energy use, are required to identify cost effective energy efficiency_x000D__x000D_
opportunities with up to a four year payback period and report publicly on their business_x000D__x000D_
response._x000D__x000D_
The underpinning program legislation came into effect in July 2006 and the program_x000D__x000D_
underwent a significant review at the end of the first five year cycle. The review found the_x000D__x000D_
program had contributed to significant improvements in energy efficiency understanding,_x000D__x000D_
focus and management in participating corporations, particularly in the areas of data_x000D__x000D_
Page 90 Policies and Measures 4_x000D__x000D_
analysis, opportunity identification and decision-making. Barriers to the uptake of cost_x000D__x000D_
effective energy efficiency opportunities, specifically relating to information, skills and_x000D__x000D_
organisational practices, had been significantly reduced. At the same time the review_x000D__x000D_
also found that some capital and non-capital barriers to implementing the identified_x000D__x000D_
opportunities remain, and that there is still scope to better embed energy management in_x000D__x000D_
core business practice._x000D__x000D_
The independent review found the program was complementary to the carbon price, as it_x000D__x000D_
addresses information market failures not targeted by a carbon price. The Government is_x000D__x000D_
making some changes to improve the program<U+2019>s flexibility and reduce the compliance_x000D__x000D_
and reporting burden on business. Medium-sized businesses are also able to participate_x000D__x000D_
in the program voluntarily._x000D__x000D_
After the first five-year cycle of the program, participating corporations reported they were_x000D__x000D_
implementing energy saving opportunities with a net financial benefit of $808 million per_x000D__x000D_
annum. This represents a saving of 1.5 per cent of Australia<U+2019>s total energy use,_x000D__x000D_
equivalent to 8.2 million tonnes per annum in emissions reductions, or 1.5 per cent of_x000D__x000D_
Australia<U+2019>s total greenhouse gas emissions. The independent review estimated that_x000D__x000D_
40 per cent of these reported savings had been directly enabled by the program.

column7: Establishment of the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA)
column8:
ARENA is a statutory authority providing research, development, demonstration and deployment grant funding to improve the affordability and increase the supply of renewable energy in Australia._x000D_
The Australian Renewable Energy Agency is a statutory authority established by the Australian Renewable Energy_x000D_
Agency Act 2011, which commenced operations on 1 July 2012. ARENA provides research, development and_x000D_
deployment grant funding to improve the affordability and increase the supply of renewable energy in Australia._x000D_
As at 30 June 2017, ARENA had committed approximately $1 billion to over 317 projects. This has been matched_x000D_
by approximately $2.5 billion in co-funding, making the total over $3.5 billion. These funds have supported_x000D_
projects spanning the commercialisation pathway, from research and development to demonstration and_x000D_
near-commercial deployment projects._x000D_
ARENA has $800 million to 2022 to support renewable energy projects. The Australian Government<U+2019>s priorities for_x000D_
ARENA include:_x000D_
<U+2022> at least double the funding allocated to research and development, consistent with Australia<U+2019>s Mission_x000D_
Innovation target._x000D_
<U+2022> funding research and development of technologies supporting electricity system security and reliability_x000D_
(such as storage)._x000D_
ARENA draws on independent expert advice (such as the Independent Review into the Future Security of the_x000D_
National Electricity Market and CSIRO Low Emissions Technology Roadmap) and works collaboratively with other_x000D_
agencies supporting clean energy innovation.

CEFC is a statutory authority that uses debt and equity funding to promote investment in clean energy technologies, namely renewable energy technologies, energy efficiency technologies and low emissions technologies and their supply chains._x000D_
The Clean Energy Finance Corporation (CEFC) is a statutory authority established by the Clean Energy Finance_x000D__x000D_
Corporation Act 2012, which commenced operations on 1 July 2013. The CEFC<U+2019>s mission is to increase the flow_x000D__x000D_
of finance into Australia<U+2019>s clean energy sector. The CEFC uses debt and equity funding to promote investment in_x000D__x000D_
clean energy technologies. The CEFC does this through direct investments which attract private sector finance,_x000D__x000D_
as well as making indirect investments through its strategic co-financing partners. Projects near commercial_x000D__x000D_
deployment can access debt and equity from the CEFC at close to market rates._x000D__x000D_
As at 30 September 2017, and since 2013, the CEFC has made cumulative investment commitments of $5 billion_x000D__x000D_
to projects with a total value of $14 billion. These projects will reduce emissions from energy and industrial_x000D__x000D_
processes, and include investments in solar energy and energy storage. The CEFC invests commercially to increase_x000D__x000D_
the flow of funds into renewable energy, energy efficiency and low emissions technologies._x000D__x000D_
Each dollar of CEFC investment commitments in 2016<U+2013>2017 was matched by more than $2 from the private_x000D__x000D_
sector. The CEFC<U+2019>s investment portfolio is expected to generate a return above the Government's costs of funds._x000D__x000D_
In 2016, the Australian Government agreed to create three new funds within the CEFC:_x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> The Clean Energy Innovation Fund (see below)._x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> The Sustainable Cities Investment Program: The Program supports the national Smart Cities Agenda by_x000D__x000D_
investing in energy efficiency, renewable energy and low emissions technology projects that improve_x000D__x000D_
Australian cities._x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> Reef Funding Program: The Program provides up to $1 billion over 10 years for clean energy projects_x000D__x000D_
benefiting the health of the Great Barrier Reef. The Reef Funding Program will contribute to the_x000D__x000D_
implementation of the Reef 2050 Plan, the overarching framework for protecting and managing the Great_x000D__x000D_
Barrier Reef._x000D__x000D_
The CEFC also works through banks and other financial institutions to offer financial products to encourage_x000D__x000D_
businesses to make sustainable purchasing choices for energy efficient equipment, fuel efficient, electric and_x000D__x000D_
hybrid vehicles, and to implement small scale behind-the-meter renewable energy projects.

The Safeguard Mechanism places emissions limits (baselines) on facilities which emit >100,000 t CO2-e per year. Facilities covered by the Safeguard Mechanism are required to reduce emissions or purchase carbon credits to ensure net emissions remain below the baseline.

On 17 October 2017 the Australian Government announced it will accept the recommendation of the Energy_x000D__x000D_
Security Board for a new National Energy Guarantee. The Guarantee will deliver more affordable and reliable_x000D__x000D_
electricity while meeting Australia<U+2019>s international commitments to emissions reduction. The Guarantee requires_x000D__x000D_
electricity retailers to contract with or directly invest in energy resources to supply an amount of dispatchable_x000D__x000D_
energy while also meeting a specified emissions level for the electricity they buy. The Government is working_x000D__x000D_
with the Energy Security Board and the states and territories through the COAG Energy Council to implement the_x000D__x000D_
National Energy Guarantee._x000D__x000D_
How it works_x000D__x000D_
The Guarantee will require energy retailers and some large energy users to ensure that the electricity they_x000D__x000D_
contract for or purchase meets both a reliability and an emissions target._x000D__x000D_
Ultimately, each individual retailer will determine how they meet the requirements under the Guarantee._x000D__x000D_
Retailers can do this within their existing portfolio of generators, by investing in new generation assets, or by_x000D__x000D_
contracting directly with generators, storage or demand response services that:_x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> the system maintains a minimum amount of dispatchable capacity to meet customer and system_x000D__x000D_
reliability needs_x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> the emissions associated with electricity purchased in the market are aligned with Australia<U+2019>s emissions_x000D__x000D_
reduction commitments under the Paris Agreement._x000D__x000D_
The independent Energy Security Board says the Guarantee will result in lower emissions and a more reliable and_x000D__x000D_
affordable energy system for Australian consumers.

The Australian Government established the $200 million Clean Energy Innovation Fund in July 2016 to support_x000D_
early stage and emerging clean energy technologies. The Clean Energy Innovation Fund is co-managed by_x000D_
the CEFC and ARENA. The Fund draws on ARENA<U+2019>s experience in the renewable energy sector, and its technical_x000D_
expertise in assessing these projects. This complements the CEFC<U+2019>s financial investment expertise._x000D_
Final approval is provided by the CEFC Board, which is responsible for all investment commitments made under_x000D_
the Clean Energy Finance Corporation Act 2012._x000D_
As at 30 September 2017, $43 million in CEFC finance for total projects worth $121 million has been invested in_x000D_
seven projects under the Clean Energy Innovation Fund. Investments include:_x000D_
<U+2022> $2 million to clean-tech company, Wattwatchers to expand production of its award-winning measurement_x000D_
technology that helps better manage energy use and costs. Wattwatchers clamp-on internet device,_x000D_
advanced control analytics and cloud-hosted management interface provide real time data showing where_x000D_
and when energy is being consumed. The multi-channel auditor device can be used to inform customers of_x000D_
energy usage and identify energy waste or poor performance._x000D_
<U+2022> $5 million to Victoria-based manufacturer SEA Electric to ramp up its conversion of medium-duty trucks_x000D_
and commercial vans to electric vehicles. The technology can be applied to businesses performing express_x000D_
freight, general delivery, and waste collection duties around Australia._x000D_
<U+2022> $5 million to GreenSync, an innovative Melbourne-based company aiming to bring smart technology_x000D_
solutions to the energy grid of the future, as part of an $11.5 million Series B capital raising (the post_x000D_
development stage)._x000D_
<U+2022> $10 million to the $50 million capital raising of Carbon Revolution, a Geelong-based company producing_x000D_
one-piece light-weight carbon fibre car wheels help reduce energy consumption and carbon emissions_x000D_
from lighter vehicles.

The Australian Government released a Low Emissions Technology Roadmap in June 2017. The Roadmap was_x000D_
developed by the CSIRO, and highlights opportunities to grow Australia<U+2019>s clean technology sector, fast track_x000D_
emissions reductions and be part of future global supply chains._x000D_
The roadmap considered the scope for new technology to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from the energy_x000D_
sector (including electricity generation, heat production, direct combustion, transport, electricity and fuel_x000D_
consumption and fugitive emissions from coal mines, coal seam gas operations and gas pipelines)._x000D_
It considered the possible mix of energy technologies to make a greater contribution to meeting Australia<U+2019>s_x000D_
2030 emissions reduction target (and longer term emissions reduction goals) at least cost. Priority was given to_x000D_
technologies where Australia can become a major part of a global supply chain._x000D_
A report under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change_x000D_
The roadmap explored the potential economic opportunities for Australian industry through deployment of_x000D_
relevant technologies or by participating in growing low emission fuel and technology supply chains._x000D_
The roadmap considered four options or <U+2018>pathways<U+2019> to decarbonisation of the energy sector, which in_x000D_
2016 accounted for 79 per cent of Australia<U+2019>s emissions._x000D_
The report found:_x000D_
<U+2022> Australia is endowed with energy-rich resources and is well positioned to benefit from innovation in_x000D_
low-emission technologies._x000D_
<U+2022> Energy productivity will remain important in reducing energy costs and emission levels throughout_x000D_
the transition._x000D_
<U+2022> While the technology pathways are comparable in terms of cost, they carry different levels of commercial,_x000D_
technical, social, and stakeholder risks._x000D_
<U+2022> Given those risks, a technology neutral approach is recommended to support the lowest-cost solutions_x000D_
to emerge.

Australia was a founding member of Mission Innovation<U+2014>a global initiative to increase public investment in clean_x000D__x000D_
energy research and development (R&D) as part of global efforts to accelerate innovation breakthroughs in clean_x000D__x000D_
energy technologies. Along with 21 other member countries plus the European Union, the Australian Government_x000D__x000D_
has pledged to double public expenditure on clean energy R&D from 2015 levels by 2020._x000D__x000D_
In joining the global Mission Innovation initiative, Australia pledged to double early stage government clean_x000D__x000D_
energy R&D expenditure to at least $216 million by 2020, equivalent to approximately US$170 million. The scope_x000D__x000D_
of Australia<U+2019>s pledge encompasses the areas of renewable energy, energy storage, fuel cells and smart grids,_x000D__x000D_
energy efficiency, nuclear energy, and carbon capture and storage._x000D__x000D_
Mission Innovation government expenditure is expected to encourage substantial private investment in new_x000D__x000D_
technology. For example, through the Breakthrough Energy Coalition, Bill Gates has committed US$1 billion_x000D__x000D_
and garnered support from 27 other billionaires across ten countries to direct capital to clean energy projects in_x000D__x000D_
participating countries._x000D__x000D_
Australia is taking a keen interest in four of the seven Innovation Challenges established under Mission_x000D__x000D_
Innovation: in smart grids, carbon capture and storage, converting sunlight, and affordable heating and cooling of_x000D__x000D_
buildings. Australia has research expertise in all seven Innovation Challenges, and the Australian Government will_x000D__x000D_
be working to support participation in the challenges across the Australian research community._x000D__x000D_
ARENA will play a key role in delivering Australia<U+2019>s Mission Innovation commitment, both by providing funding_x000D__x000D_
for clean energy R&D, and by supporting participation in the Innovation Challenges. The Australian Department_x000D__x000D_
of the Environment and Energy will work with the Australian Research Council and the CSIRO to encourage more_x000D__x000D_
funding proposals from the clean energy R&D community. These agencies will develop strategic work programs_x000D__x000D_
for R&D aimed at enhancing global collaboration and increasing the chances of breakthrough technologies_x000D__x000D_
coming to fruition._x000D__x000D_
For more information on Australia<U+2019>s Mission Innovation pledge see: http://mission-innovation.net/participatingcountries/australia/.

The Solar Communities program provides $5 million in funding for community groups to install rooftop solar_x000D__x000D_
panels, solar hot water and solar-connected battery systems. It will support local responses to climate change and_x000D__x000D_
deliver lower electricity costs for community organisations._x000D__x000D_
Funding for the program is targeted to specific regions and commenced in the first half of 2017._x000D__x000D_
The Food Rescue Charities Program provides a further $1.2 million to support four charities to invest in solar,_x000D__x000D_
batteries and energy efficient refrigeration systems. The program directs practical investment to help food_x000D__x000D_
rescuers reduce their energy costs by switching to renewable energy, increasing their capacity to rescue and store_x000D__x000D_
more food and reducing greenhouse gas emissions by reducing the amount of food ending up in landfill.

The Australian Government has committed up to $110 million for an equity investment, if required, to secure_x000D__x000D_
the delivery of a solar thermal project in Port Augusta, South Australia. This investment will diversify energy_x000D__x000D_
generation and storage technologies and create new employment opportunities.

The National Energy Productivity Plan (NEPP) aims to accelerate a 40 per cent improvement in Australia<U+2019>s energy_x000D__x000D_
productivity by 2030. It consolidates national, state and territory government and industry measures to provide a_x000D__x000D_
national framework and an initial economy-wide work plan._x000D__x000D_
The NEPP aims to boost competitiveness and growth, help families and businesses manage their energy costs and_x000D__x000D_
reduce emissions. This is being done through a package of 34 measures which support:_x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> smarter energy choices (by providing more efficient incentives, empowering consumers and promoting_x000D__x000D_
business action)_x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> better energy services (by driving greater innovation, more competitive and modern markets and updating_x000D__x000D_
consumer protections and standards)._x000D__x000D_
Key achievements of the NEPP include:_x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> Tighter energy standards for equipment: the Equipment Energy Efficiency (E3) program delivers a single,_x000D__x000D_
integrated program on energy efficiency standards and energy labelling for equipment and appliances._x000D__x000D_
To accelerate the impact of the E3 program, new proposed standards have been consulted on for air_x000D__x000D_
conditioners, commercial refrigerated display cabinets, industrial fans, swimming pool pumps, lighting,_x000D__x000D_
refrigerators and freezers. These measures will deliver an estimated $7 billion in economic benefits and_x000D__x000D_
reduce emissions by 45 MtCO2_x000D__x000D_
-e (cumulative to 2030)._x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> Expansion of the Commercial Building Disclosure program: requires most sellers and lessors of large office_x000D__x000D_
spaces to provide energy efficiency information to prospective buyers and tenants. From 1 July 2017 the_x000D__x000D_
mandatory disclosure threshold for buildings size was lowered from 2,000 square metres to 1,000 square_x000D__x000D_
metres. This will lead to an estimated $50 million in new energy savings, and about 3.5 MtCO2_x000D__x000D_
-e reduction,_x000D__x000D_
calculated on a five year program duration, between the years of 2015 and 2019._x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> Improved energy efficiency of residential buildings: targeted industry training and tools are being_x000D__x000D_
delivered to improve compliance with the energy performance requirements of the Australian National_x000D__x000D_
Construction Code, and ensure residential buildings are built to need less energy for heating and cooling._x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> Robust energy use data: the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) is_x000D__x000D_
creating an Energy Use Data Model to understand Australians<U+2019> energy consumption and influencing factors_x000D__x000D_
such as a change in climate, exponential growth in use of solar electricity, and increasing energy efficiency._x000D__x000D_
Further improvements to the NEPP are underway. These include consideration of opportunities to improve energy_x000D__x000D_
productivity in the Australian Government<U+2019>s operations and the introduction of cost-reflective electricity pricing_x000D__x000D_
and competitive metering. The COAG Energy Council has committed $8 million in its 2016<U+2013>17 budget to support_x000D__x000D_
collaborative work on a number of measures. NEPP measures include:_x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> Funding of $160,000 over 2017<U+2013>18 for Victoria to develop a pilot of the Victorian Residential Efficiency_x000D__x000D_
Scorecard<U+2019>s assessment tool, which measures the energy efficiency of existing homes. This will allow_x000D__x000D_
jurisdictions across Australia to test the Scorecard<U+2019>s assessment tool._x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> Implementation of the Australian Government<U+2019>s Smart Cities Plan, including the $100 million a year_x000D__x000D_
Sustainable Cities Investment Fund. The aim is to accelerate the deployment of clean energy, renewable_x000D__x000D_
energy and energy efficiency technology in cities. This will be partially driven through negotiation of initial_x000D__x000D_
City Deals._x000D__x000D_
<U+2022> The Townsville City Deal, Australia<U+2019>s first, was signed on 9 December 2016. The Launceston City Deal was_x000D__x000D_
signed on 20 April 2017. The Australian Government and NSW Government will work together with local_x000D__x000D_
governments across Sydney<U+2019>s West and South-West Districts towards a landmark Western Sydney City_x000D__x000D_
Deal<U+2014>the first in New South Wales.

column7: Climate Change and Greenhouse Gas Reduction Act 2010
column8:
In 2010 the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Government released the Climate Change and Greenhouse Gas_x000D_
Reduction Act 2010 (the Act) http://www.legislation.act.gov.au/a/2010-41/current/pdf/2010-41.pdf. The Act promotes the development of policies and practices to address climate_x000D_
change, set targets to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and to provide for monitoring and reporting in relation_x000D_
to these targets. The ACT has committed to the following targets, which have been re-enforced by the_x000D_
ACT<U+2019>s 9th Parliamentary Agreement to the Legislative Assembly:_x000D_
<U+2022> a legislated target of 100 per cent renewable energy (electricity) by 2020_x000D_
<U+2022> a legislated emissions reduction target of 40 per cent below 1990 levels by 2020_x000D_
<U+2022> carbon neutral government operations by 2020_x000D_
<U+2022> a legislated emissions reduction target of 80 per cent below 1990 levels by 2050_x000D_
<U+2022> a legislated target of net zero1_x000D_
 greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, at the latest.

column7: Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan (AP2)
column8:
The Australian Capital Territory Government released their second Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan (AP2) in 2012. AP2 outlines_x000D__x000D_
how the ACT will achieve its 2020 targets and provides a framework for achieving long- term targets out to 2050._x000D_
http://www.environment.act.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0006/581136/AP2_Sept12_PRINT_NO_CROPS_SML.pdf

Measures for switching to renewable energy sources (solar and wind energy,_x000D_
biomass), the connection to district heating, the installation of modern biomass boilers and the construction of combined power and heating systems_x000D_
are being subsidized within the framework of environmental promotion in accordance with the Environmental Support Act (Umweltf<U+00A8>orderungsgesetz,_x000D_
UFG). In the period from 1994 to 1996 such_x000D_
projects with a total investment volume of approx. ATS 440 mill. were financially supported by_x000D_
investment subsidies of approx. ATS 130 mill. in_x000D_
accordance with the Environmental Support Act_x000D_
(biomass heating plants for individual operations,_x000D_
biomass district heating and combined heat and_x000D_
power plants based on biomass).

In February 1994 a general agreement between the Republic of Austria, represented by the Federal_x000D_
Minister of Economic Affairs, and the Austrian Association of Electricity Utilities (VE<U+00D6>), was_x000D_
48_x000D_
concluded initially for three years. In order clearly to improve compensation for electricity supplied_x000D_
from photovoltaic and wind power stations as well as from generation plants operating the basis of_x000D_
biomass or landfill gas or clarification gas, the agreement provides for subsidies in the amount of_x000D_
100% and 20% respectively for the corresponding delivery prices applicable in each case for the_x000D_
utility company drawing the electricity. The compensation paid for supplies from photovoltaic and_x000D_
wind power stations will therefore be raised up to ATS 1.75 per kWh (in the winter peak tariff), and_x000D_
up to ATS 1.05 per kWh (100 ATS is approx. 9 US$) for supplies from biomass installations as well_x000D_
as landfill and clarification gas installations._x000D_
By early June 1994 a total of seven provincial companies and provincial capital utility companies as_x000D_
well as a number of small and medium-sized power supply companies had acceded to the agreement.

column7: Levies on natural gas and electricity
column8:
As of 1 June 1996 levies on natural gas (ATS 0.60/_x000D_
m3) and electricity (ATS 0.10/kWh) entered into_x000D_
force (Natural Gas and Electricity Levies Act, Energy Levy Reimbursement Act) and by means of financial compensation 11.835% of the tax yield will_x000D_
be appropriated to the federal provinces for additional funding of environmentally sound and energy_x000D_
saving measures. In order to avoid double taxation_x000D_
heating oils and natural gas used in the production_x000D_
of electric energy are exempt from mineral oil tax_x000D_
and energy levies, respectively. For businesses with_x000D_
a focus on the production of physical assets these_x000D_
energy levies are limited to 0.35% of the net production value. For 1997 a tax yield from energy_x000D_
levies in the amount of ATS 7 billions has been_x000D_
budgeted.

As of 1 May 1995 the existing mineral oil tax rates_x000D_
were increased by between 50% and 150% and a tax_x000D_
on liquid gas for heating purposes, prior to this date_x000D_
not subject to taxation, was introduced. Fuels subject to mineral oil tax do not fall under the ceiling of_x000D_
the Energy Levy Reimbursement Act (Energieabgabeverg<U+00A8>utungsgesetz ). Contrary to other Member_x000D_
States with high tax rates on energy, there will be_x000D_
no reduced tax rates for fuels used in the industrial_x000D_
sector.

column7: Preferential framework conditions for combined heat and power production (CHP)
column8:
Within the Federal Electricity Act, the Lander are_x000D_
entitled to oblige net-operators to feed in electricity_x000D_
from combined heat and power (<U+2018>cogeneration<U+2019>) at_x000D_
macro-economically reliable prices. Such preferential_x000D_
conditions are allowed to be granted until the_x000D_
end of 2004.

column7: Energy tax rebates for combined heat and power production (CHP)
column8:
Austria<U+2019>s energy taxation system exempts <U+2018>input<U+2019>-_x000D__x000D_
fuels for power production from mineral oils and_x000D__x000D_
natural gas taxes in order to avoid double taxation_x000D__x000D_
due to the <U+2018>output<U+2019>-tax (= consumption tax) on_x000D__x000D_
electricity. On the contrary, heat from (sole) heating_x000D__x000D_
plants is taxed indirectly by the taxes on inputfuels._x000D__x000D_
Accordingly, for combined heat and power,_x000D__x000D_
only a share of input fuels is exempted from taxes._x000D__x000D_
In order to give incentives for heat production from_x000D__x000D_
cogeneration, efficient cogeneration plants benefit_x000D__x000D_
from tax rebates within the mineral oils and natural_x000D__x000D_
gas tax since 1996. Plants with a minimum electricity performance of 44% are exempted from_x000D__x000D_
taxes on <U+2018>heat share<U+2019> of energy output.

column7: Rural funding schemes for energy from biomass
column8:
The Ministry of Environment, the L<U+00E4>nder and_x000D_
the European Union also provide funding for rural_x000D_
biomass energy projects. Total public funding_x000D_
for those projects, like district heating from wood_x000D_
chippings, biogas CHP or individual biomass heating_x000D_
systems amounted to roughly 25 million annually_x000D_
over the past years._x000D_
The L<U+00E4>nder receive a share of 11,835% of the energy_x000D_
tax revenue (electricity and gas) that is to be_x000D_
spent for these and other environmental purposes._x000D_
Since the federal electricity tax was raised by 100%_x000D_
in mid 2000, L<U+00E4>nder now receive additional 25_x000D_
million per year for relevant support schemes, giving_x000D_
more flexibility to step-up resource allocation_x000D_
for renewables and district heating. For instance,_x000D_
Lower Austria announced in 2001 that it would_x000D_
quadruple provincial funding for biomass district_x000D_
heating from 1.45 to 5.8 million annually.

The Federal Environment Fund is enabled to fund_x000D_
environment projects with a total budget frame of_x000D_
actually more than <U+00A4>40 million per year. Over the_x000D_
past years, increasing priority has been given to climate_x000D_
change related projects. In 2000, 70% of the_x000D_
funding sum was dedicated to projects with direct_x000D_
implications on GHG emissions, and that share will_x000D_
even be extended. For the budget periods 2001 and_x000D_
2002, the total budgetary frame has been increased_x000D_
to reach <U+00A4>40 million and <U+00A4>47 million, respectively,_x000D_
after <U+00A4>36 million on average during past years. All_x000D_
additional funding (i.e. <U+00A4>15 million for both years)_x000D_
will be channelled for climate change purposes._x000D_
Over the past years, funding focused on biomass_x000D_
and biogas district heating, entrepreneurial biomass_x000D_
central heating systems, solar panels and energy_x000D_
efficiency measures, small hydro and wind_x000D_
power stations and thermal renovation of entrepreneurial_x000D_
buildings.

From the date of entry_x000D_
into force of the law in October 2001, 8% of_x000D_
electricity delivered to consumers has to be produced_x000D_
in small hydropower plants. That is roughly_x000D_
the actual share of small hydro in the distribution_x000D_
grid in Austria, but under the conditions of_x000D_
rising electricity demand, further investments will_x000D_
be needed to increase power production from that_x000D_
source, in absolute terms. Without legally binding_x000D_
targets, no sufficient economic incentives would_x000D_
be in place, either to revitalise elder small hydro_x000D_
stations or to invest in new ones._x000D_
In difference to the feed-in price policy for <U+2018>new_x000D_
renewables<U+2019>, a trading scheme for <U+2018>small hydro certificates<U+2019>_x000D_
has been in operation since October 2001_x000D_
to guarantee compliance with the target in a costeffective_x000D_
manner._x000D_
For the purpose of consumer information, electricity_x000D_
companies and traders have to indicate on the_x000D_
electricity bill the primary energy mix used for the_x000D_
production of electricity they deliver.

To make the renewable energy targets economically attainable, the prime ministers of the L<U+00E4>nder_x000D_
have to fix feed-in-tariffs according to the_x000D_
production costs of N-RES-electricity and an extra_x000D_
grid-charge for recovering the additional costs_x000D_
(resulting from the fixed feed-in-tariffs) to the regional_x000D_
distributors.

Grid operators have the duty to take over electricity_x000D__x000D_
from renewable energy sources generated by independent_x000D__x000D_
producers, either industrial or others. A_x000D__x000D_
quantified target for so called <U+2018>new renewable energy_x000D__x000D_
sources<U+2019> (N-RES, i.e. electricity from wind,_x000D__x000D_
solar, biomass, biogas, geothermal energy) was determined_x000D__x000D_
at 3%, to be achieved by supply grid operators_x000D__x000D_
by 2005 (as a first step). Due to the amendment_x000D__x000D_
of the Austrian Electricity Act in 2000, which_x000D__x000D_

column7: Increase the share of renewable energy in energy supply and district heating

Increasing the share of renewable energy sources in the public power and heat supply is the main policy to reduce climate impacts of the energy system. Large-scale hydro power for electricity generation has delivered a significant contribution to power supply since the first half of the last century._x000D_
In order to provide for further growth of renewable sources, quantitative targets for 2020 for the increase of the share of wind power, photovoltaics, small hydro plants and biomass/biogas in electricity generation have been laid down in the Green Electricity Act and shall be achieved by fixed feed-in tariffs. After similar previous regulations the current instrument to achieve this policy target is the Green Electricity Act 2012 (Federal Law Gazette I No. 75/2011 as amended) and the respective Feed-in Tariff Ordinance. Tariff support is provided for plants installed until 2020 for a limited period._x000D_
For biomass-based district heating systems investment support is granted under the Domestic Environmental Support Scheme and serves to increase the share of biomass in heat supply.

column7: Financial support for the production of electricity from RES

In January 1995, the Electricity and Gas Control Committee approved financial support (EUR 0.025/kWh) for the production of renewable electricity (including electricity produced from biogas and organic waste, but excluding small photovoltaic production units) for supply to the network. On 1 July 1998, an additional <U+201C>green franc<U+201D> (EUR 0.025/kWh) was awarded to wind and hydroelectric installations with a capacity on a single site of at least 10MW. This support will be provided for a period of 10 years. This_x000D_
action will be evaluated in 2003. For small photovoltaic units (<3 kW), compensation between purchases and sales from the client to the network is exceptionally authorised throughout the lifetime of the installation. With an adapted electricity meter (able to record both the consumption from- and supply to the network), this results in a selling price to the network of ~ EUR 0.15/kWh.

column7: Eligibility of the producers and consumers of green electricity
column8:
The Federal Government decided, on 5 April 2000, that every producer of electricity from RES will be_x000D_
progressively free to choose their electricity supplier for any additional needs they might have (foreseen_x000D_
or for emergencies). Furthermore, clients who purchase a significant proportion of electricity derived_x000D_
from RES are eligible to freely choose their supplier of electricity. The federal legislation, while_x000D_
interpreting the European directives on the liberalisation of the energy markets, also promotes_x000D_
combined heat and power: producers of <U+201C>quality<U+201D> CHP electricity will become eligible clients more_x000D_
rapidly. This policy was reaffirmed by the Council of Ministers in its decision of April 2000. The_x000D_
Flemish and Walloon Regions will also provide the immediate eligibility of producers and consumers of_x000D_
renewable electricity or electricity derived from CHP for access to the liberalised segment of the_x000D_
electricity market. Likewise, in Brussels-Capital Region, independent producers of green electricity (or_x000D_
electricity derived from CHP) will be immediately eligible for their additional needs.

The Federal Government has formally recorded the necessity of establishing a system of renewable_x000D_
energy certificates (<U+201C>green certificates<U+201D>), by which the electricity suppliers undertake to derive part of_x000D_
their electricity from RES. The Federal Government has approved, on 7 December 2001, the project of_x000D_
Royal Decree concerning the green certificates; this decree sets the minimum proportion of electricity_x000D_
derived from renewable energy at 6% by 2010. Suppliers that cannot meet this condition will be required_x000D_
to pay fines._x000D_
The Flemish Government has also taken the option of imposing a minimum standard (3% by the end of_x000D_
2004, 5% in 2010) for the proportion of renewable energy on the electricity suppliers, by means of a_x000D_
system of green certificates. The supplier fulfils its obligations by depositing a certain volume of green_x000D_
certificates annually. These have to be deposited with the regulatory body of the Flemish Region. If it_x000D_
happens that one of these suppliers cannot satisfy its obligations, a fine is imposed. These fines will_x000D_
supply a fund that will be used for the promotion of renewable energy resources. Finally, the transport_x000D_
of renewable electricity via the distribution network is exempted of taxes. A similar system of_x000D_
certificates will be introduced for CHP._x000D_
In the Walloon Region, <U+201C>green<U+201D> electricity will be also be promoted by the system of green certificates,_x000D_
plus via a system of support to production. The priority is the use of biomass, including various types_x000D_
of biodegradable waste. Then small-scale hydro-electricity (<10 MW), active and passive solar heating_x000D_
applications, and wind energy are coming in. The suppliers will be required, under pain of paying a fine,_x000D_
to supply a growing proportion of electricity from RES (some 4% in 2004 and 12% in 2010) and, with_x000D_
certain weighting, from <U+201C>quality<U+201D> CHP. In Brussels-Capital Region, as in the two other regions, a system of green certificates will be set up. Two_x000D_
sorts of obligations will be imposed on electricity suppliers: firstly the annual submission of green_x000D_
certificates (whose number is yet to be determined by the regional government), and secondly the_x000D_
purchase of the surplus green electricity (or electricity derived from CHP) produced by independent_x000D_
producers.

The National Climate Plan is based on all the policies and measures contained in the regional climate plans and those for which the federal authorities are competent. It was drawn up first and foremost to enable Belgium to meet its obligations under the Kyoto Protocol._x000D_

policies._x000D__x000D_

and measures rolled out by the various_x000D__x000D_
competent authorities so as to develop_x000D__x000D_
synergies and identify complementary_x000D__x000D_
approaches, while taking into consideration the respective competences of_x000D__x000D_
these bodies._x000D__x000D_

interest) have been identified for this_x000D__x000D_
purpose:_x000D__x000D_
Six sectoral strategic areas have been_x000D__x000D_
defined:_x000D__x000D_
1. Optimisation of energy production_x000D__x000D_
2. Rational use of energy in buildings_x000D__x000D_
3. Influence on industrial processes_x000D__x000D_
4. Development of sustainable means_x000D__x000D_
of transport_x000D__x000D_
5. Encouragement of the sustainable_x000D__x000D_
management of agricultural and forest ecosystems_x000D__x000D_
6. Boosting of waste management efforts_x000D__x000D_
The plan contains five additional broader-based strategic areas:_x000D__x000D_
7. Stepping up of research on climate_x000D__x000D_
change_x000D__x000D_

change_x000D__x000D_
